title: 113_hr3311
content: The Act is titled the "Provide Access and Retain Continuity Act" or the "PARC Act". It involves agreements for the continued operation of certain facilities and programs. The PARC Act requires the Secretary of the Interior to enter into agreements with States for conducting activities described in section 3. States can submit a petition to the Secretary for an agreement, which will be approved or denied within 30 days of submission. The PARC Act requires the Secretary of the Interior to enter into agreements with States for conducting activities described in section 3. States can submit a petition to the Secretary for an agreement, which will be approved or denied within 30 days of submission. Petitions must be resubmitted within 90 days if corrected, and the Secretary will deny a petition if incomplete or if the proposed agreement lacks required terms. States with previous agreements terminated may have their new petitions denied based on past termination reasons. If a petition is denied, the State will receive written notice. If the Secretary does not approve or deny a petition within 90 days, it is deemed approved. The petition must include a clear statement of reasons for denial and any deficiencies. States can amend and resubmit denied petitions. A petition submitted under subsection (b) must include a letter from the Governor describing eligible activities, the proposed agreement, proof of the State's ability to conduct activities, a statement of indemnification for negligence, and any additional required documentation by the Secretary. SEC. 3. ACTIVITIES ELIGIBLE FOR REIMBURSEMENT. The Secretary of the Interior will reimburse States for non-Federal funds spent on activities meeting specific criteria during a Federal Government shutdown. These activities must be necessary for facilities or programs with a direct economic impact on tourism, mining, timber, or transportation in the State. During a Federal Government shutdown, the Secretary of the Interior will reimburse States for non-Federal funds spent on activities that are necessary for facilities or programs with a direct economic impact on tourism, mining, timber, or transportation in the State. The reimbursed activities must not be substantially greater in scope or cost than if conducted by the Federal Government and must not involve settling or defending against liability claims by the State. The waiver of sovereign immunity allows States to bring actions against the United States for reimbursement of non-Federal funds spent on activities related to section 3.
